summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons investigative report concerning an incident on July 23, 2019, where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found with a homemade noose around his neck in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The report details the incident, subsequent medical assessments, and interviews with Epstein and his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, concluding there was insufficient evidence of an assault and no need for inmate separation. This document is a Bureau of Prisons Form 583 Report of Incident and related staff memoranda detailing the events of July 23, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found with an orange cloth around his neck in an apparent suicide attempt. The reports include conflicting narratives from Epstein and his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, and detail the staff response and subsequent medical assessment. This document contains medical records, incident reports, and administrative forms from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York related to a possible suicide attempt by inmate Jeffrey Epstein on July 23, 2019. It includes a clinical encounter describing his injuries, photo sheets documenting the incident, an administrative detention order, an incident report, and a separate medical encounter for his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the report, found with a homemade noose around his neck in his cell. He was interviewed and claimed he was extremely tired and did not recall the incident clearly.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate at the time of the incident. He was interviewed and stated he was asleep when he felt something hit his foot, then observed Epstein on the floor. He reported a prior conversation where Epstein made him uncomfortable.

persons.name: Covington, T
persons.context: Appears as a signatory on the Daily Assignment Roster page.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: Inmate at MCC New York who was found with a rope around his neck in his cell on July 23, 2019, and was examined by medical staff. He was placed on suicide watch and administrative detention.

persons.name: Nicholas John Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). He was examined separately on July 31, 2019, and stated he had no idea what happened to Epstein and had no injuries.

persons.name: MLP
persons.context: Medical provider who examined Jeffrey Epstein on July 23, 2019, documenting the marks on his neck and placing him on suicide watch.

persons.name: PA-C
persons.context: Medical provider who examined Nicholas Tartaglione on July 31, 2019, in the SHU.

persons.name: Lieutenant
persons.context: MCC staff member referenced in the medical note, incident report, photo sheets, and administrative detention order. Requested medical encounters and authorized Epstein's placement in administrative detention.

connections.description: Were housed together in the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York. Epstein stated he had no issues with Tartaglione, while Tartaglione reported keeping conversation minimal and being uncomfortable with some of Epstein's statements.
Were housed together in cell 124 in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York at the time of the incident on July 23, 2019.
Correctional supervisor involved in the response to the incident, authorized Epstein's administrative detention, and requested medical follow-ups.
Conducted the clinical examination of Epstein after he was found with injuries, documented his condition, and initiated the suicide watch plan.
Conducted a medical evaluation of Tartaglione following the incident with his cellmate Epstein.

events.title: Epstein Found with Homemade Noose
events.description: At approximately 1:27 a.m., staff found inmate Jeffrey Epstein lying in a fetal position on his cell floor with a homemade noose around his neck. He was breathing heavily and responsive. He was restrained, medically examined, and placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Interview with Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Epstein was interviewed by SIS staff. He stated he had not slept in about twenty days, was extremely tired, and only recalled getting up for water before being on the floor. He denied feeling suicidal or threatened by his cellmate.

events.title: Interview with Nicholas Tartaglione
events.description: Tartaglione was interviewed. He stated he was asleep when he felt something hit his foot, then saw Epstein on the floor with his eyes open. He called for help, thinking Epstein was having a heart attack. He recounted a prior uncomfortable conversation with Epstein.

events.title: Epstein Placed in Administrative Detention
events.description: An Administrative Detention Order was issued, placing Jeffrey Epstein in detention pending classification.

events.title: Epstein Apparent Suicide Attempt in MCC
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with an orange homemade rope/cloth around his neck, unresponsive but breathing. Staff responded, removed the ligature, and transported him to medical observation. Conflicting accounts emerged from Epstein and his cellmate about the cause.

events.title: Epstein Accuses Cellmate of Murder Attempt and Extortion
events.description: After becoming responsive, Epstein told staff he believed his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, tried to kill him and had been trying to extort money from him for a week, threatening to beat him up.

events.title: Medical Assessment of Epstein
events.description: Epstein was examined by medical staff (MLP) at 6:20 AM, noting a circular line of erythema (redness) at the base of his neck with friction marks and a small erythema on his left knee. He reported no memory of the event.

events.title: Possible Suicide Attempt by Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell (124) with an orange homemade rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. Staff responded, removed the rope, and he was unresponsive but breathing. He was later examined by medical staff.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch and Administrative Detention
events.description: Following the incident, Epstein was placed on suicide watch. An administrative detention order was issued citing a 'serious threat' to his safety, placing him in detention pending classification.

events.title: Medical Examination of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: MLP examined Epstein after the incident. He had a circular line of erythema (redness) around the base of his neck and a small mark on his left knee. He was ambulatory, oriented, smiling, and stated he did not know what happened or how he got the marks.

events.title: Medical Examination of Nicholas Tartaglione
events.description: PA-C examined Tartaglione in the SHU. He stated he felt good, his anxiety was better, and he had 'no idea what was going on' with his previous cellmate (Epstein). He denied any injury.

keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his prison cell with a homemade noose around his neck, resulting in visible injuries to his neck and knee.
Epstein told investigators he had not slept in approximately twenty days and was extremely tired, offering an explanation that did not suggest a suicide attempt or assault.

Cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione reported a prior conversation where Epstein stated, 'fourteen (14) is legal in most states and I don't understand what's the problem here,' which made Tartaglione uncomfortable.
The Bureau of Prisons investigation concluded there was insufficient evidence to support that Epstein was assaulted by Tartaglione and recommended no inmate separation was warranted.
Epstein was placed on suicide watch following the incident and later stated he felt safe with his new cellmate and was able to sleep with his CPAP machine.
Jeffrey Epstein was found in his MCC cell at ~1:27 AM on July 23, 2019, with an orange homemade ligature around his neck, in an incident documented as a suicide attempt.

Epstein later accused his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, of attempting to kill him and of a week-long campaign of extortion and threats, claiming Tartaglione said staff would not report an assault due to Epstein's charges.
Tartaglione's account was that he was asleep, felt something on his legs, turned on the light, and saw Epstein with a string around his neck, prompting him to call the guards.

Medical examination found a circular red line with friction marks on Epstein's neck and a small red mark on his left knee, but Epstein claimed no memory of the incident, saying he just went for water and woke up snoring.

The document includes multiple staff memoranda describing the response, indicating Epstein was initially unresponsive but later observed opening his eyes to look at staff and pretending to be unconscious.
On July 23, 2019, at approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his MCC New York cell with an orange homemade rope around his neck, in what was documented as a 'Possible Suicide Attempt.'

Epstein's medical examination shortly after revealed a 2-inch wide circular line of erythema (redness) around the base of his neck with marks of friction, but he was ambulatory, oriented, smiling, and claimed he did not know what happened or how he got the marks.
Epstein was immediately placed on suicide watch and later into administrative detention for his own protection, citing a 'serious threat' to his safety.
Epstein's cellmate at the time was Nicholas Tartaglione, who was separately examined days later and stated he had 'no idea what was going on' and had no injuries.
The document includes multiple standardized 'Photo Sheets' from the MCC's Special Investigative Section documenting the incident and the condition of both inmates' cells.
